bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, August 23, 1941

div1.p: Hench discusses identification of the figures in Cornwell's painting for an upcoming "Hygeia" article that will feature a copy of the painting. He presents a strong argument for including Ames.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, August 23, 1941
div1.p:
First let me thank you and Mr. Cornwell most sincerely for the beautifully
framed autographed sketch of Walter Reed. I am very proud to have this and it will
hang in my office in the Mayo Clinic beside one of the colored reproductions of
the painting which I hope soon to have. In this, as in all your dealings with me,
you and your associates have been extremely kind.

Now let me transmit to you the suggestions of Generals Kean and Truby and
of myself regarding the identification of the as yet anonymous figures in the paint-
ing. I can understand your amused pleasure to find that Matas and others have so
promptly and so self-satisfyingly nominated names for the anonymous figures. Look-
ing at it in a narrower light, you are of course glad to have this painting mean
“all things to all men” and for them to see in it whomever they wish to see in it.
I do not criticize you for this view and there is much to be said in favor of it.
In the last analysis it is for you and your associates to decide whether you wish
to “leave the door open.”

But I have thought much about this and have taken the liberty to suggest
more specificity in identification. Let's take a long range view. I believe as
time passes this portrait will assume more and more historical significance and I
believe that posterity will demand considerable specificity; history will demand
as much accuracy in naming the figures as Cornwell's conscience demanded in hav-
ing correct uniforms. Posterity will say (at least I think so): “Who is that and
that and what right has he to be in the portrait?”

Because I feel this way I was delighted that you designated the two seated
figures Major Kean and Gen. Wood and that Mr. Cornwell changed the original insignia
(as shown in the earlier sketches) to those appropriate to the rank of the Major
and General. Indeed even the poses of these men are appropriate--Kean leaning for-
ward with intense interest, Wood looking on more aloofly, with hand to mouth as if
pondering the tremendous significance of the work in hand and also remembering the
risks he and the others were assuming if things went wrong.

I like the symbolism of the group of soldier volunteers, waiting and ready
to be the next to be experimented upon. I like the eager interest of those officers
who, though subordinate in scientific rank to the principles and therefore placed
somewhat in the background, nevertheless played an important and vital part one way
or another. I am so glad Dr. Cooke and Gen. Truby are specifically named.

Now for the figures un-named or tentatively named. It has been my under-
standing (and I believe Mr. Cornwell told me in his studio) that the mustached
red-headed private on Moran's right (to our left of Moran) was more or less drawn
Mr. George A. Kellogg
- 2 -
August 23, 1941
after Jernegan so chosen because he was one of the most-used volunteers (he under-
went every test offered) and especially because his mustache made him picturesque
and different. (He is #14 in the enclosed old photo of the hospital detachment.)
Both Generals Truby and Kean agree that Jernegan has an excellent right to be
specifically included.

The Spanish immigrant (and if I used the words “Cuban volunteer” in any
previous correspondence it was a slip of the tongue because Cubans were supposedly
immune, and hence newly arrived Spanish immigrants were used)--this immigrant might
well remain unnamed but specifically designated “a figure representing the four
Spanish immigrants who volunteered for the experiments, (namely Antonio Benigno, Nicanor Fernandez,
Vincente Presedo, Jose Martinez)”. (I have given the names in the
order of their getting yellow fever.)

The rather obscured American volunteer in the background between Moran and
the Spanish immigrant also might well be specifically designated "a figure repre-
senting one of the additional eleven American soldiers who volunteered, namely
William H. Dean, William Olson, Levi Folk, W,Wallace
Folk,
John
Andrus, Clyde West, James Hanberry,
Charles Sonntag, Edward Weatherwalk, James Hildebrand, Thomas England. (The first
eight are named in the order they developed yellow fever; the last three lived in
the infected clothing building and never got the disease.)

This leaves only the two officers on the porch railing. You say that Dr.
Cooke is the figure in white. That's alright with me. Dr. Cooke certainly should
be in it. But if you see his picture (#4 in the hospital corps group) you will see
that neither of the officers on the porch rail resembles Cooke too closely. Indeed
I believe the officer in the brown coat perhaps looks a bit more like Dr. Cooke
than the figure in white. However, I leave that up to you and Cornwell.

Who shall the other one be? Were he a private he might well go un-named
and merely be another “representative” but since he is an officer and fairly
prominant I think he should be named. One of your earlier correspondents suggested
including Dr. Carter (whose paper, next to that of Finlay, was Reed's most important
stimulus) but as Gen. Kean points out in the enclosed (excerpted) letter Carter
was only tangentially related to the experiments and may or may not have been in
Cuba. Capt. Stark was commanding officer of the Post Hospital except for the short
time when Lieut. Truby hold that position, but he had probably less actual connection
with the mosquito work than Truby, and since the latter is included I don't believe
Stark need be in it also. Dr. Pinto might be mentioned--he was one of the earliest
persons experimented upon, but the early volunteers accepted the experiments most
casually; they expected nothing and nothing happened. Pinto (who is still living
in Omaha) did not get yellow fever, did not volunteer later, and hence doesn't seem
to rate.

About the only other person I can suggest is Dr. Roger Post Ames (now dead,
widow living) who was the hospital's chief yellow fever expert, who was the head man
who took care of the spontaneous yellow fever cases at the post prior to the experi-
ments and who faithfully and most successfully cared for all the experimental cases
brought back from Camp Lazear to be cared for at the post. Probably largely because
of his skill and care not one volunteer died of experimental yellow fever (except
Lazear, of course). It seems to me and to Gen. Truby that Dr. Ames thus deserves
Mr. George A. Kellogg
- 3 -
August 23, 1941
first consideration for the un-named figure.

In the official Senate Document (page 71) Reed's paper states: “The
personnel of this camp (Camp Lazear) consisted of two medical officers, Dr.
Roger P. Ames, acting assistant surgeon, United States Army; an immune,
in immediate charge: Dr. R. P. Cooke, acting assistant surgeon, United States
army, nonimmune....” (Moran disputes this and says he never saw Ames while he,
Moran, was at Camp Lazear, that Ames stayed at Columbia Barracks. But I believe
it was either Gen. Truby or Gen. Kean who told me that they accepted the record
and Reed's statement and that though Ames probably only went to the camp when
someone got sick, he nevertheless was “officially” in charge). Despite this
contention Ames would seem the most worthy because of his care of the volunteers.
Note what Gen. Truby says in the enclosed letter. You will note that Gen. Kean
is not so definite in approving his name but I have sent him a copy of Truby's
letter today and he (Gen. Kean) will presumably write you directly to reach you
air mail Monday morning. If Gen. Kean nominates somebody else, by all means
take his suggestion as he ranks as the greatest living authority on these experi-
ments.

It is doubtless too late to take Gen. Truby's suggestion to do the face
over from a photo to be obtained from Mrs. Ames. Ames is not in the group photo
enclosed. But the Ames family will probably not worry too much over the dubious
likeness if Dr. Ames is honored by inclusion. As to the appropriateness of the
uniform and insignia I cannot venture to speak, but both the white coated and the
brown coated officers appear to be lieutenants; their shoulder insignia resemble
those worn by Dr. Cooke (#4 in the group photo) and both were contract surgeons
with the rank of “acting assistant surgeon” (same as Lazear). So the uniform
insignia would not seem to be inappropriate for Dr. Ames if you decide to include
him.

All of the foregoing I send you simply in a spirit of helpfulness. You can
do whatever you want about it. I assure you, and we who are interested by-standers
will abide by your decision and respect your final judgment. I will send a copy
of this letter airmail special to Generals Kean and Truby. I imagine Gen. Truby
has made his final comment but there is still time for Gen. Kean to let you hear
from him Monday before your deadline.

By the way, please refer to General Kean as Chief Surgeon, Department of
Western Cuba (and not as “head of the U. S. Military Hospital in Havana” as noted
erroneously in the New York Mirror). If you want to add a further citation, he was
friend and advisor to Reed and his associates (and did more for Reed than any other
outsider with the possible exception of Gen. Wood).

May I suggest that when you make up your description for Hygeia and the A.M.A.
you send a carbon copy airmail to Generals Kean and Truby and to me. If there is
any last minute correction or slip I'm sure they will advise you in time to correct
proof.

closer.seg:
P. S. What final inspiration was responsible for the cigarette on the
table? Was Cornwell smoking one when he gave the painting its finishing touches, and
did he figuratively lay it down “in the painting” with a sigh of relief? Or did
Carroll smoke? I've chuckled ever that final touch.
